ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze media through the lens of Nietzche's Dionysian/Apollonian dichotomy. In broader terms, the class taught me how media throughout the ages has explored themes of revelry and pleasure as a vice versus as a virtue.
This course teaches students about Dionysus role in Greek literature and modern society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Interesting and fun class, good readings, but sometimes discussion got a little off topic
This class offers a great overview of a seemingly narrow topic that can be extended to various other famous works of art.
The strengths of the class include its weekly papers, which provide opportunities to practice writing, and its eccentric syllabus. The weaknesses include the unclear feedback throughout the course.
The strength of the class is definitely in its strong syllabus; the weakness is definitely Professor Syrimis teaching style.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This class is a great experience for any student looking for an interesting humanities course that won't take too much time out of their schedule. As a seminar-based course, this class can be what you make of it depending on how you contribute to class discussions, which are very open.
Yes! Its an unorthodox class, but you will thoroughly enjoy it.

I would not recommend this course to another student, even though I would certainly recommend a lot of the reading material to another student. Professor Syrimis made me uncomfortable numerous times... a lot of his lessons and his ideas just seemed untrue and unprofessional.
